greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Second-order Lucas numbers; a(n) = (2n+3)*Lucas(n) - n*Lucas(n-1).
comment: This sequence is defined by analogy with the sequence of second-order Fibonacci numbers A010049.
Inverse binomial transform is (-1)^n * a(n). - _Michael Somos_, Jun 02 2014
link: Colin Barker, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..1000
Index entries for linear recurrences with constant coefficients, signature (2,1,-2,-1).
formula: Recurrence: a(0) = 6, a(1) = 3, a(n+2) = a(n+1) + a(n) + 5*Lucas(n).

Set A(n) = (a(n-1) + a(n+1))/5, B(n) = a(n+1) - a(n-1). Then A(n+2) = A(n+1) + A(n) + 5*Fibonacci(n) and B(n+2) = B(n+1) + B(n) + 5*Lucas(n). The polynomials L_2(n,-x) = sum {k = 0..n} C(n,k)*a(n-k)*(-x)^k appear to satisfy a Riemann hypothesis; their zeros appear to lie on the vertical line Re x = 1/2 in the complex plane. Compare with the polynomials L(n,-x) defined in A132148.
mathematica: a[ n_] := 3 (n + 1) LucasL[n] - n LucasL[n + 1]; (* _Michael Somos_, Jun 02 2014 *)
results.author: _Peter Bala_, Oct 24 2007
